question: Question_05
statement:
Show that if \emph{d} is an odd squarefree integer then a necessary
condition for the equation $\displaystyle x^2 -d  y^2 = -1$ to have an
integer solution is that all the primes dividing \emph{d} must be of the
form $\displaystyle 4n + 1$.
sols:
We proceed as in the hints. Suppose that in fact \emph{d} was of the
form $\displaystyle 4n + 3$. Then since

$\displaystyle (4k + 1)(4m+1) = 4(4km + k + m) + 1$

we know that there must be a prime \emph{p} of the form
$\displaystyle p = 4j + 3$ that divides \emph{d}. Reducing modulo
\emph{p} gives

$\displaystyle x^{2} \equiv -1 \mod{p}$

This means that $\displaystyle \left(\frac{-1}{p} \right) = 1$. However,
Euler's criterion tells us that
$\displaystyle 1 = \left(\frac{-1}{p} \right) \equiv (-1)^{(p-1)/2} = (-1)^{2j+1} =-1 \mod{p}$
and this is a contradiction.
hints:
Your first reaction might be to use the theory of Pell equations and
continued fractions on this problem, but there is a much more elegant
solution.

Suppose that in fact \emph{d} was of the form $\displaystyle 4n + 3$.
What can we conclude about prime divisors of \emph{d}?

Recall that the product of two primes of the form $\displaystyle 4k + 1$
must be a number of the form $\displaystyle 4m + 1$.

Use a sub-case of quadratic reciprocity or Euler's criterion to finish
the problem.
